description: From Middle English fle, from Old English flēah, flēa, from Proto-West Germanic *flauh, from Proto-Germanic *flauhaz (compare West Frisian flie, Low German Flo, Flö, Dutch vlo, German Floh, Icelandic fló), from pre-Germanic *plóukos, *plówkos, from Proto-Indo-European *plúsis (compare Latin pulex, Sanskrit प्लुषि (plúṣi)).
The archaic plural fleen is from Middle English fleen, flen, from Old English flēan (“fleas”).

entries.meaning: A small, wingless, parasitic insect of the order Siphonaptera, renowned for its bloodsucking habits and jumping abilities.

verbs.description: flea (third-person singular simple present fleas, present participle fleaing, simple past and past participle fleaed)
flea (third-person singular simple present fleas, present participle fleaing, simple past and past participle flead)

examples: […]  he'd flea me alive like another St Bartholomew.
